item.title: Differentiation
item.description: Normally if without any statements, \( f \) is a real-valued continuous function on \( [a,b] \) Definition of differentiation Definition For a function \(f\), defined on interval \([a,b]\). For \(x \in [a,b ]\) \[\lim_{t \to x } \frac{f(t) - f(x)}{t - x} \] is called the differentiate of f at x, denotes by \(f’(x)\). Apparently, to let \(f’(x)\) exists, the function has to have left/right limit (or both) at the point \(x\).
